Solution to Question 1:
The WHO states that the perinatal period commences at 22 completed weeks and ends at seven completed days after birth - 154 days. It corresponds to when the fetus weighs 500g or more.
This definition is not to be confused with the period used for the calculation of the perinata mortality rate (PMR). To calculate the PMR, a fetal weight above 1000 g is considered, which is achieved at 28 weeks of gestation. Therefore, for all statistical purposes, internationa comparisons, and calculation of perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is considered.
Perinatal period: from the 22nd week.
Perinatal mortality rate calculation: from the 28th week.
The neonatal period is defined as the first 28 days after birth. Infancy is defined as the first year of life.
The image below shows various time periods. Only the time period for perinatal mortality and the perinatal period are different as shown in the image. For others, corresponding mortality rates are calculated using the same time periods shown.

Solution to Question 6:
Neonates do not generate heat by shivering.
Heat production in neonates happens by increasing the metabolic rate and oxygen consumption by releasing norepinephrine, which results in non-shivering thermogenesis through
beta-oxidation of brown fat. This sympathetic surge also causes cutaneous vasoconstriction.
Increased physical activity - crying, increased body movements, and muscular activity also contribute to thermogenesis.
Preterm and small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants have scanty brown fat stores.

Solution to Question 8:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.
KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—
Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
Early discharge and ambulatory care.
Support for mother and family for child care. Evidence shows that-
It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
Humanization of neonatal care
Promoted bonding between mother and child E igibility criteria for KMC:
It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.
Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.
Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.
The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.
KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation. Note:
Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

Solution to Question 12:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin.
Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component
responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin).
Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next few weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system. Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools.
Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.
Solution to Question 13:
The parachute reflex has its onset at 7–8 months of age. It is fully developed by 10-11 months of age and remains throughout life.
It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.
This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia.
In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.
The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fa backward onto the examiner’s hand.

Solution to Question 15:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.
The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).
An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.

Solution to Question 17:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis.
Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.
These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum.
Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines.
Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after
birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.
Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with vacuum-assisted delivery.

Solution to Question 8:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.
Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.
Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs).

Other markings-
A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life.
C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.
D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.
Solution to Question 9:
Left-hand paralysis with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis in a newborn suggests a diagnosis of Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome.
There is an injury to the 7th-8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve. This produces
a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected, and the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1 thoracic root are also injured.
Option A: Erb–Duchenne paralysis affects the 5th and 6th cervical nerves. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. Moro's reflex is absent on the affected side.
Option B: Phrenic nerve palsy (3, 4, and 5 cervical nerves) results in diaphragmatic paralysis. It is characterized by cyanosis and irregular and labored breathing.
Option C: Horner's syndrome is characterized by miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos, anhydrosis, and loss of ciliospinal reflex.

ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical.
This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does.
It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs.
Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).

Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by

Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.
Photo-oxidation: minor method

The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia to start IV glucose is a blood glucose level of <40 mg/dL.
Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when the blood glucose is <45 mg/dL. Clinically in neonates, hypoglycemia can be asymptomatic or symptomatic. The neonate presents with tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, tachypnea, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and rarely cardiac arrest.
Management in symptomatic neonates:
Blood glucose <40mg/dL: IV glucose infusion
Blood glucose <25mg/dL: Bolus IV dextrose 1-2 mL/kg followed by infusion at the rate of 5-8mL/kg/min.
Management in asymptomatic neonates:
Breastfeeding within 30 minutes
Start IV glucose therapy if blood glucose <35 mg/dL
Recheck blood glucose before the next feeding
Continue skin-to-skin care
Evaluation for other underlying illnesses
The desired target glucose value is >50mg/dL and blood glucose should be rechecked until three normal values.

In an infant of a diabetic mother with normal blood glucose levels, the next investigation to consider is serum calcium due to the high risk of developing hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia in these infants is attributed to the delayed response of the parathyroid hormone system.
Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium concentration of less than 8 mg/dL for a term baby (ionized calcium below 4mg/dL) and less than 7 mg/dL for a preterm baby. Asymptomatic neonates can be managed conservatively with early nutrition. Symptomatic neonates should receive iv or oral calcium replacement.
Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperglycemia, and the fetal pancreatic response leads to fetal hyperinsulinemia, which causes neonatal hypoglycemia. Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose <40 mg/dL (plasma glucose <45 mg/dL). The infant tends to be jittery, tremulous, hyperexcitable, hypotonic, lethargic, and poor sucking during the 1st three days after birth. These symptoms can also be related to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia which occur in the 1st 24 to 72 hours of life.
Respiratory distress syndrome, macrosomia, hyperbilirubinemia, polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis, visceromegaly, heart failure, and persistent pulmonary hypertension are other features seen in infants of diabetic mothers.
Congenital anomalies are seen in infants of mothers with pregestational diabetes. Neural tube defects (Encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels (TGA), ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen.
Caudal regression syndrome is rare, but a specific anomaly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.

Solution to Question 1:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

Congenital umbilical hernia- This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Solution to Question 5:
The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type.
A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
Other options:
Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies.
Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation.
Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment.

Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm infants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor.

Breast milk protects against necrotizing enterocolitis.

Solution to Question 4:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order
to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100 mmHg.
Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended.
The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically. It may produce a vagal response - apnea and/or bradycardia due to stimulation of the nerve in the posterior pharynx.
Solution to Question 5:
The ratio of compressions to ventilation in the resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths in one minute).
A 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation where compromise of gas exchange is nearly always the primary cause of the cardiovascular collapse.
Chest compressions are indicated if the heart rate is below 60/min even after 30 seconds of positive pressure ventilation. Once the HR is 60/min or more, chest compressions should be discontinued.

Solution to Question 7:
Room air is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants.
Resuscitation with room air in term infants is as effective as using 100% oxygen. By using room air, we may reduce the risk of hyperoxia which is associated with decreased cerebral blood flow and generation of oxygen free radicals.
If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increased concentrations of oxygen are administered until normal saturation levels are achieved.
If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. Resuscitation of most preterm infants can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%).

It allows time to secure the airway in an infant known to have airway obstruction due to various causes, including laryngeal atresia or stenosis, teratomas, hygromas, and oral tumors before the infant is separated from the placenta. Option A: Separation anxiety begins at about 9 months of age. Children wake up crying from their naps as they realize that their parents are not in the same room as them. A developmental delay should be suspected if the development quotient (DQ) is below 70%. It is calculated as:
DQ = Developmental age x 100Chronological age
From the highest milestones achieved by the child, the developmental age in a particular domain is calculated. The chronological age is the actual age in term babies. However, in preterm infants, a corrected age rather than postnatal age is used till two years of age. This is used to account for the small gap in neurological development that premature children have yet to catch up. For example, a child born at 32 weeks gestation (gestational age) seen at 12 weeks of age (postnatal age), should be considered as a 4-week-old (corrected age) child.
If there is a delay (DQ<70%) in more than 2 domains, then global developmental delay (GDD) is suspected.

Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.
Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain -glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.
Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)
It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding.
Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement.
Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is risk of aspiration.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. In edematous malnutrition, the initial appearance of edema is commonly observed in the feet and lower legs, progressing into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face. The skin over the swollen areas may show dark, crackled, peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin underneath, making it susceptible to infections.
There may be sparse and easily pluckable hair. Hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration is a common finding. Associated symptoms of misery, apathy, and loss of appetite are seen in children with edema.
Other options:
Option B: Marasmus is a severe form of wasting characterized by significant loss of fat and muscle tissue as the body utilizes these resources for energy. It is often triggered by acute starvation or illness in individuals with borderline nutritional status.
Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a chronic liver disease that affects infants and young children. Common symptoms include jaundice, pruritus, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The disease progresses rapidly, leading to the development of cirrhosis.
Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node enlargement.

Solution to Question 12:
Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14. The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:
Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.
Mnemonic: SHIELDED
Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia)
Hypothermia
Infection
ELectrolyte imbalance
DEhydration
Deficiency of nutrients
Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks. Steps:
Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
Start cautious feeding: Give ù to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made
which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.

After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
Transfer to home-based diet

Solution to Question 1:
Vitamin A is required for the maintenance of epithelial functions, creating an effective barrier against pathogens; hence, it is called as an anti-infective vitamin. So, vitamin A deficiency can lead to changes in the epithelia of all mucosal surfaces, leading to increased chances of infections.
Vitamin E (Tocopherol) helps is an anti-oxidant. Deficiency manifests as skin changes and hair loss.
Vitamin D maintains calcium and phosphorus homeostasis. Deficiency can lead to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.
Vitamin C helps in the formation of connective tissues and collagen in the skin, bone, and blood vessels. Deficiency leads to their fragility and causes scurvy.

The girl is suffering from measles. It is associated with vitamin A deficiency.
Vitamin A deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infection and increased mortality with a variety of infectious diseases particularly measles. Hence, vitamin A therapy is indicated in all patients with measles.
The main functions of vitamin A are as follows:
Maintenance of vision, especially night vision
Maintenance of epithelial tissues
Differentiation of various tissues, particularly during reproduction and gestation, by regulating gene expression.
Features of vitamin A deficiency:
Eyes: Defective dark adaptation is a characteristic early clinical feature, resulting in night blindness (earliest manifestation). This can further progress to xerophthalmia, Bitot's spots, conjunctivitis, or keratomalacia, leading to blindness.
Poor overall growth, anaemia

Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical image is showing Bitot spots, which occur due to keratinization of the conjunctival epithelium. Bitot spots are triangular, frequently bilateral, and present on the bulbar conjunctiva.
Normally, bulbar conjunctiva is a stratified, columnar, non-keratinized epithelium. In vitamin A deficiency, there is squamous metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin admixed with gas-forming bacteria producing a dry, scaly patch with a foamy appearance called Bitot spots.
Option A: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva is termed conjunctival concretions, which usually occurs over the palpebral conjunctiva, in chronic inflammatory conditions of the eye.
Option B: Scarring of the conjunctiva is seen in chlamydial infection of the eye. Option C: Excessive growth of conjunctival tissue is seen in the pterygium of the eye.

Both hypervitaminosis A and deficiency of vitamin A cause raised intracranial pressure (ICP) (not just hypervitaminosis A). 11-cis retinal(not trans) is required for vision.
Hypervitaminosis A causes headache, vomiting, desquamation of the skin, and hyperostosis of long bones. Rupture of lysosomes in the cells is the pathological feature of hypervitaminosis A.
All-trans retinoic acid is the most bioactive form of vitamin A, and it is required for cell differentiation and the regulation of transcription. On the other hand, 11-cis retinal is required for vision. Protein-energy malnutrition can cause vitamin A deficiency because of the impaired synthesis of retinol-binding protein (RBP).

Vitamin E/ Tocopherol is a potent antioxidant and is helpful in preventing hair fall. It promotes hair growth and prevents hair roots from getting damaged by free radical injury.
Alpha-tocopherol is the active component of vitamin E and it is mainly located within cell membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and the formation of free radicals.
Deficiency of this can also lead to neurological defects, hemolysis, and posterior column defect. Treatment includes vitamin E supplementation (25–50 units/day for a week).
Note:
The other vitamins having antioxidant properties are vitamins A, C, and E (vitamin E is the most important).
The other vitamin beneficial in the treatment of hair fall is biotin.

It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of muscle control), delayed mental development, diarrhoea and dermatitis (pellagra-like symptoms as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin). Solution to Question 1:
In an infant with diarrhoea, the initial fluid of choice is oral rehydration solution (ORS).
The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.
Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction of stool output, decrease in vomiting and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia. Other home available fluids that can be used are salted rice water/salted yoghurt drinks, vegetable/chicken soup with salt.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock.
The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.
Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available
within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia. Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion:

Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration.
Hypernatremia causes movement of water from brain cells into hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within brain. This leads to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.
The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death.

Solution to Question 16:
Color blindness is primarily inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. The genes for color vision are located on the X chromosome.
Males have a single X chromosome inherited from mothers. If the X chromosome inherited carries a mutation, males exhibit the disease. However, females become carriers of the color blindness gene and have a 50% chance of passing it on to their children.
Female carriers usually are protected because of the random inactivation of one X chromosome. But there is a possibility that the mutant X chromosome remains active if the normal alleles are inactivated in some of the cells so the heterozygous female can express the disorder partially.
The image shows the pattern of X-linked inheritance:

In color blindness, the mechanism to appreciate one or more primary colors is either defective (anomalous) or absent (anopia). It may be congenital or acquired. Congenital color blindness can be dyschromatopsia (defective color vision of any one of the RGB colors) or achromatopsia (complete color blindness of all three RGB colors). RGB colors are red, green, and blue.
Tests for color blindness include the Ishihara test, Hardy–Rand–Rittler test, and Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test.

Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) or Louis–Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder.
The defect in AT is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11q22-23. The ATM gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to combined immunodeficiency (impaired immunoglobin isotype switching and association with thymic hypoplasia) and predisposition to an increased risk of lymphoreticular tumors such as lymphoma or leukemia.
AT is characterized by progressive ataxia (beginning during infancy), telangiectasia (initially on bulbar conjunctiva), sinopulmonary infections, hypogonadism, sensitivity to ionizing radiation, insulin resistance, and raised alpha-fetoprotein levels.

Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.

Solution to Question 1:
Mousy odor is characteristically seen in phenylketonuria due to excess phenylacetate (phenyl ketone) formed in the body.
In the absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase, phenylalanine enters into alternate metabolic pathways which result in the formation of phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, and phenylacetylglutamine.
Solution to Question 2:
The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue.
High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barrier causing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine and tryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis.
Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growth retardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density and osteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages.
Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) that are excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNS damage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition.
Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause is hyperphenylalaninemia.
Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include:
Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen
Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color
Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated
Enzyme studie
Genetic mutation studie
Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.
Solution to Question 3:
Defects of either phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) can cause hyperphenylalaninemias.
PAH deficiency is diagnosed as phenylketonuria.
Malignant hyperphenylalaninemias include three enzyme defects, dihydropteridine reductase,pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthase, and GTP cyclohydrolase which help in BH4 synthesis. The deficiency of BH4 impairs three hydroxylase(phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan), and severe neurological symptoms develop because of the lack of neurotransmitters.
Dihydropteroate synthase is present only in bacteria and this makes it a useful target for sulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.
Solution to Question 4:
A low-phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment of PKU.
The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain. Because phenylalanine is not synthesized endogenously, small amounts of phenylalanine should be added to the diet to prevent phenylalanine deficiency. Dietary deficiency of this amino acid is manifested by lethargy, failure to thrive, anorexia, anemia, rashes, diarrhea, and even death; moreover, tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in this disorder and its adequate intake must be ensured.
Sapropterin dihydrochloride , a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients with residual PAH activity, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to reduce phenylalanine levels in PKU.
Solution to Question 5:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 is caused by the deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAAH).
Elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine are diagnostic for tyrosinemia type I.
Liver(jaundice, acute hepatic crisis, elevated serum transaminases), kidney(hypophosphatemia), and nerve damage(extensor hypertonia of neck and trunk) are caused by metabolites of tyrosine degradation, especially fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, and is usually precipitated by minor infections.
A diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine can slow but does not halt the progression of the condition. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits 4-HPPD and reduces the flux of tyrosine metabolites to FAH, thus decreasing the production of the offending compounds, fumarylacetoacetate, and succinylacetone.

Solution to Question 6:
Corneal ulceration is not a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1. In fact, ocular manifestations are a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 which presumably occur due to tyrosine deposition.
Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).
Features of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (hepatorenal tyrosinemia):
An acute hepatic crisis commonly heralds the onset of disease, which may progress to liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death.
Episodes of acute peripheral neuropathy resembling porphyrias often triggered by a minor infection, such crisis can be associated with paralytic ileu
Renal involvement, which is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and vitamin D–resistant ricket
The treatment of choice for HT Type 1 is nitisinone, which blocks early steps in the tyrosine degradation pathway and limits the formation of toxic tyrosine metabolites.
Note:
Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

Palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability are seen in hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (Richner–Hanhart syndrome/ oculocutaneous tyrosinemia)
Treatment with a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine aiming to achieve plasma tyrosine levels
<500 µmol/L improves skin and eye manifestations. The image below shows herpetiform corneal ulcer:

Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase.
It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability.Untreated patients have
marked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal, as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.

Solution to Question 9:
Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditary tyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases in plasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 µmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of

hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine.
Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening for hypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent.
Note:
Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasma tyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturity of 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding, and decreased motor activity. Hypertyrosinemia usually resolves
spontaneously in the first 2 months of life. Treatment includes a low protein diet and vitamin C.

Solution to Question 10:
The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD.
In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affected individuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites.
Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial with large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.

The following condition is characterized by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.
The image represents ochronosis: Bluish-black pigmentation of the ear cartilage and/or sclera due to deposits of accumulated homogentisic acid.
This is characteristically seen in alkaptonuria. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed, which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues. Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening of the urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.

Solution to Question 16:
The treatment of Hartnup disease is not with the supplementation of tryptophan. Hartnup disease
It is caused by a defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic (neutral) amino acids, including tryptophan, by the intestinal mucosa and renal tubules.
There is a defect in B0AT1 protein in the intestine/ renal tubules or both, which is caused by a mutation in SLC6A19.

A pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients, and some patients may have intermittent ataxia.
Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by Obermeyer test.
Treatment is with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.

Solution to Question 18:
The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) which is due to deficiency of branched-chain
-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH).
Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme.
Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to -ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine,
alanine, and aspartate). -Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normal function of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema and referred to as leucinosis.
Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milder forms, and orthotopic liver transplant.

Solution to Question 20:
Biotin is the treatment of choice for multiple carboxylase deficiency.
Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism. Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.
Neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting.
Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus.
Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological doses of biotin.
It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:
Pyruvate carboxylase
Acetyl CoA carboxylase
Propionyl CoA carboxylase

Solution to Question 2:
All of the above agents are used in the treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant. Treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant:
Provide adequate calories, fluid, and electrolytes intravenously.
Minimal amounts of protein as a mixture of essential amino acids during the first 24 hours of therapy.
Give priming doses of the following compounds: Sodium benzoate, Sodium phenylacetate, Arginine hydrochloride.
Initiate peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis if the above treatment fails to produce an appreciable decrease in plasma ammonia levels.
Benzoate forms hippurate with endogenous glycine in the liver. Each mole of benzoate removes 1 mole of ammonia as glycine.
Phenylacetate conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is readily excreted in the urine. One mole of phenylacetate removes 2 moles of ammonia as glutamine from the body.
Arginine administration supplies the urea cycle with ornithine. It is effective in all patients, except those with arginase deficiency.
Note:
Phenylbutyrate which is metabolized to phenylacetate in our body can also be used as it scavenges nitrogen.

Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine, which can become a substrate for the OTC reaction when ornithine is deficient.
Components of HHH syndrome:
Hyperammonemia
Hyperornithinemia
Homocitrullinemia

-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is also called plumboporphyria/Doss porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, although it is not related to lead exposure.
ALAD catalyzes the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole porphobilinogen (PBG). The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it.
Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and
symptoms. Symptoms resemble those of other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of abdominal pain and neuropathy.

Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual.
Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.
Solution to Question 9:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of I-cell disease or inclusion cell disease. It is also known as type II Mucolipidosis.
It is an autosomal recessive inherited as a lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused due to a defect in N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase required for the Golgi to phosphorylate mannose residues on glycoproteins. This leads to defective mannose-6-phosphate, an important cell signaling molecule required for trafficking of the lysosomal enzyme from the site of its production in the endoplasmic reticulum to the lysosome. Due to this defect, the lysosomal enzymes are secreted out of the cell and there is an increased serum concentration of the same. Intracellularly, there are abnormal inclusion bodies and vacuolizations, thus earning the disease its name.
Clinically, these patients present with symptoms either at birth or early in life with growth retardation, failure to thrive, delay of developmental milestones, coarse facial features with a cloudy cornea and gingival hypertrophy, and other non-specific findings such as hip dislocations, inguinal hernias, hepatomegaly, joint limitation, and skin changes.
Investigations to establish a diagnosis may include
measuring N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs or in cultured fibroblasts and estimating serum levels of lysosomal enzymes.
Option B: Galactosemia is caused due to the complete absence of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate (galactose-1-P) to uridine diphosphate galactose. It is characterized by typical clinical features such as jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, poor feeding, lethargy, diarrhea, E.Coli sepsis. Infants may also have edema, ascites, full fontanelle, encephalopathy, and excessive
bruising and bleeding. They tend to develop cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol.
Option C: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of -oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.
Option D: Hurler syndrome is an important diagnosis in a patient presenting with clinical features given in this clinical vignette. But it is a mucopolysaccharidosis type 1-H caused due by the defect in the -L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate. It is characterized by skeletal abnormalities, hepatosplenomegaly, and severe intellectual disability.
Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, a wide nasal bridge, and a flattened midface. Features such as hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical or inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex laos are also seen. They also have developmental delays and recurrent sinopulmonary diseases. Failure to thrive and growth restriction are also seen.

Gaucher's disease:
It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase
(-glucosidase) that leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomes of cells.
It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.
The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues.
There are 3 clinical subtypes, delineated by the absence or presence and progression of neurologic manifestations: type 1, or the adult, nonneuronopathic form; type 2, the infantile or acute neuronopathic form; and type 3, the juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form
Typical clinical features include delayed puberty, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, hypersplenism and pancytopenia, bleeding tendencies, bone pain due to avascular necrosis, osteoporosis, pathological fractures.
Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3).
Bone marrow examination usually reveals the presence of Gaucher cells (have a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance)

Andersen's disease is type IV glycogen storage disease. It is transmitted in an autosomal recessive pattern and occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme because of pathologic variants in the GBE1 gene. Growth delay
Hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points
Myopathy

Treatment: Complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet. With age, symptoms become milder even after fructose ingestion. The long-term prognosis is good.

Solution to Question 1:
Poliovirus mainly affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and medulla oblongata (cranial nerve nuclei), causing lower motor neuron (LMN) type of paralysis. It damages motor and autonomic nerves; sensory nerves are not involved.
Poliovirus is a non-enveloped, positive-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) are known. Ages 6 months to 5 years are most commonly affected. The virus is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and has an incubation period of 8-12 days. Humans are the only known reservoir for the polioviruses.
The virus colonizes and replicates in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into the blood via regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord.
Most cases are subclinical. Some have minor illnesses like fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. It can present as non-paralytic polio (aseptic meningitis) or paralytic polio (flaccid paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes). Most frequently, the completely affected muscle is the tibialis anterior. It is asymmetric paralysis which is more severe if strenuous physical exercise occurred during the onset of paralysis. Death usually occurs due to respiratory paralysis.
Vaccination schedule for polio:
Live attenuated: oral polio vaccine (OPV) (Sabin) at birth (day 0); then boosters at 6, 10, and 14 weeks and at 15-18 months; additional doses till 5 years
Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) (Salk) given intradermally; two fractional doses at 6 and 14 weeks as well as 9 months of age.
Solution to Question 2:
Most of the outbreaks of paralytic polio are caused by the type 1 virus.
Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) of poliovirus are known. Poliovirus type 1 has historically been the predominant cause of poliomyelitis worldwide and continues to be transmitted in endemic areas.
Most infections with poliovirus are asymptomatic. Rarely, patients can have the following presentations:
Abortive poliomyelitis - a minor illness, manifested by fever, malaise, sore throat, or headache.
Non-paralytic poliomyelitis - manifested by aseptic meningitis.
Paralytic poliomyelitis - aseptic meningitis followed by severe back, neck, and muscle pain with rapid/gradual onset of motor weakness. It is the least common presentation of poliovirus infection.
Wild poliovirus type 2 was eradicated in 1999. Until 2015, over 90% of cVDPV (circulating vaccine-derived polioviruses) cases were due to the type 2 component in OPV.
Bivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) contains serotypes 1 and 3. Serotype 2 has been removed, as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic poli (VAPP).
Note:
On 25 April 2016, India switched from trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to bivalent OPV; this day is called the National switch day.

(OPV).
VAPP is said to occur if:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal tetanus. It is caused by a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani, which inhibits inhibitory neurons, not excitatory neurons.
Clostridium tetani is a spore-forming obligate anaerobe commonly found in soil, dust, and gastrointestinal tracts of various animals. The baby's umbilical stump covered with cow dung serves as the source of infection. It also occurs in infants of unimmunized mothers. Tetanus typically manifests within 3-12 days of birth as progressive difficulty in feeding, rigidity, or spasms.
Tetanus toxin binds at the neuromuscular junction and enters the motor nerve; it is then transported to the alpha-motoneuron via retrograde axonal transport. Subsequently, the toxin enters the adjacent spinal inhibitory interneurons, where it prevents the release of the neurotransmitters glycine and -aminobutyric acid. This leads to blockade of normal antagonistic muscle inhibition, while agonist muscles undergo sustained contraction without relaxing.
Neonatal tetanus presents with progressive feeding difficulty (sucking and swallowing), irritability, and crying. Characteristic features include reduced movement or complete muscle paralysis, rigidity, and spasms. These features may or may not be associated with opisthotonos.
Treatment includes supportive care in the form of muscle relaxants (diazepam), along with the administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and metronidazole, which is the antibiotic of choice. Parenteral penicillin G can serve as an alternate antibiotic.
Excising the umbilical stump in a baby with neonatal tetanus is no longer recommended.

The likely cause of seizures in a child who has multiple ring-enhancing lesions and dietary history of pork intake is an infection with Taenia solium.
Children acquire the adult form of the parasite by ingestion of undercooked pork containing larvae cysts. In the intestines, the cyst converts into adult form. The adult form releases eggs in the stool.
If the eggs are ingested (shed by tapeworm carriers or by unhygienic practices), the larvae are released from the eggs. The larva then invades through the intestines and migrate through the bloodstream to the muscles (and other organs), where they form tissue cysts called cysticercosis. When these larvae find their way to the brain, it is termed as neurocysticercosis.
Neurocysticercosis typically presents with seizures (focal or generalized). It can be associated with basilar arachnoiditis that can present with signs of meningeal irritation. Cysticerci in the tissues may present with focal findings from the mass effect. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, an electrolyte and acid-base imbalance characteristically seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).
A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis and plasma HCO3- is 30 mmol/L, which is in the higher range. Both these findings indicate metabolic alkalosis.
Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality.
i.e Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is
called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.
CHPS typically presents with the following:
Non-bilious vomiting, which is progressive, maybe projectile, occurring immediately after a feed, usually presents after the 3rd week of age.
As the vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, chloride ions, and potassium leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
Hyperbilirubinemia is the most common clinical association of pyloric stenosis, which is also known as the icteropyloric syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus. It is more common in males. Risk factors include Down's syndrome and RET oncogene.
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrograffin enema (image shown above).
The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel.
A rectal suction biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis and operative intervention is the definitive treatment.
Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:
Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
NOTE:
In the fetus, migration of the neuronal crest tissues to form myenteric plexus and ganglion cells is completed by the 24th week of life. If interrupted in migration, it results in Hirschsprung disease.

Solution to Question 1:
Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of gastroenteritis in children. It accounts for 29% of deaths caused by diarrhoea in children aged < 5 years.
Solution to Question 2:
The risk of death from diarrhoea is increased in the presence of deficiencies of micronutrients such as vitamin A, and zinc (2 and 4 only).
Both these micronutrients are essential for maintaining mucosal immunity. Vitamin A deficiency increases mortality from diarrhoea, measles, and malaria while Zinc deficiency increases mortality from diarrhoea, pneumonia, and malaria.
Recent studies also indicate the usefulness of folic acid in the prevention of diarrhoea.

Osmotic diarrhoea results from the presence of osmotically active, poorly absorbed solutes in the bowel lumen that inhibit normal water and electrolyte absorption. This type of diarrhoea ceases with fasting.
Secretory diarrhoea, infective diarrhoea, dysentery and motility diarrhoea occurs independent of dietary intake and do not subside with fasting.

Persistent diarrhoea(Chronic diarrhoea) is defined as a diarrhoeal episode that lasts for more than 14 days.
Diarrhoea is defined as
stool volume of more than 10 g/kg/day in toddlers/infants (or)
stool volume greater than 200 g/day in older children
Persistent diarrhoea is increasingly observed in children with malnutrition. These are due to infections commonly caused due to enteroadherent Escherichia coli and Aeromonas.
Acute diarrhoeas generally last less than 7 days while chronic diarrhoea lasts more than 14 days and is usually a non-infectious pathology.
Solution to Question 5:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of acquired lactose intolerance which is an example of osmotic diarrhoea.
Lactose is present in milk and dairy products. If it is not absorbed in the small intestine, it reaches the colon, where it is fermented to short-chain organic acids. This releases hydrogen that can be detected in the lactose breath test and also generates an osmotic overload.
The child with lactose intolerance generally has perianal excoriations. The condition is diagnosed by using stool examination which shows acidic stool positive for reducing substances. Treatment is by diet control using a diet devoid of lactose. It can be congenital due to lactase deficiency or acquired after post-viral gastroenteritis. In secretory diarrhoea, the epithelial cells’ ion transport processes are turned into a state of active secretion. The most common cause of acute-onset secretory diarrhoea is a bacterial infection of the gut.
Chronic diarrhoea is, in many cases, the result of an intestinal infection that persists longer than expected.
Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread by means of faeco-oral transmission.

Solution to Question 9:
Isotonic dehydration with acidosis is the most common finding in children with severe viral enteritis.
Viruses that cause human diarrhoea selectively infect and destroy the villus tip cells in the small intestine.
In the small intestine, the upper villus enterocytes are differentiated cells, which have absorptive functions, such as the transport of water and electrolytes. On the other hand, the crypt enterocytes are undifferentiated cells and are net secretors of water and electrolytes.
Selective viral infection of intestinal villus tip cells thus leads to decreased absorption of salt and water (proportionate loss of water and salt—isotonic dehydration) and an imbalance in the ratio of intestinal fluid absorption to secretion.
Metabolic acidosis may be a result of stool bicarbonate losses in children with diarrhoea. These can also be seen due to secondary renal insufficiency or lactic acidosis as a sequelae to diarrhoea.

Solution to Question 14:
Serum elastase is not used for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. The measurement of faecal elastase is used as a screening test for pancreatic insufficiency.
The criteria for the diagnosis of pancreatitis in children is defined as 2 of 3 of the following:
Epigastric abdominal pain;
Serum amylase and/or lipase activity at least 3 times greater than the upper limit of normal; and
Imaging findings characteristic of, or compatible with, acute pancreatitis.
Serum lipase is now considered the test of choice for acute pancreatitis as it is more specific than amylase.

The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is an amniotic fluid test used to assess fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio of < 2 in amniotic fluid indicates lung immaturity.
Surfactant starts appearing in the fetal lung by 20 weeks of gestation. Levels indicating lung maturity are detected after 35 weeks.
Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates produced by type II pneumocytes in the lung epithelium. The absence of surfactant in the liquid film lining the alveoli causes an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse. If not treated, such atelectasis leads to increased work of breathing, intrapulmonary shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and eventually respiratory failure.
The relative concentration of the phospholipids lecithin (L) and sphingomyelin (S) is an indicator of lung maturity. The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. An L–S ratio of 2.5 or more indicates fetal lung maturity while an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

maturity. Lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio at 31 to 32 weeks is 1, and at 35 weeks ratio is 2. The ratio 2 indicates lung maturity (option A).
The shake test or bubble test (Clement's test) (option B) involves mixing amniotic fluid with 95% ethanol, shaking it for 15 seconds, and observing it for 15 minutes. A complete ring of bubbles at the meniscus is a positive test and indicates lung maturity. This is a useful bedside test.
The presence of phosphatidylglycerol, (option C) saturated phosphatidylcholine and lamellar body count (>50,000/mcL) indicates lung maturity.
Glucocorticoids accelerate lung maturation and lower the incidence of respiratory distress and eonatal mortality in preterms if the birth was delayed for at least 24 hours after initiation of
betamethasone. A single course of corticosteroids is recommended for women between 24 and 36 weeks who are at risk of delivery within 7 days. Intramuscular injections of either 2 doses of 12 mg betamethasone are given 24 hourly or 4 doses of 6 mg dexamethasone are given 12 hourly.

Solution to Question 16:
Respiratory distress in a post-term neonate with a history of greenish (meconium-stained) amniotic fluid during delivery is suggestive of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS). The aspirated meconium can block the large and small airways, causing patchy atelectasis and emphysema. This produces a ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Severe overinflation can lead to air leak syndromes such as pneumothorax.
Meconium consists of water, desquamated GIT cells, skin, lanugo hair, vernix, bile salts, pancreatic enzymes, lipids, and mucopolysaccharides. The bile salts and pancreatic enzymes can cause chemical pneumonitis. Meconium can also cause surfactant inactivation by displacing it from the alveolar surface and inhibiting its surface tension-lowering ability. Severe MAS is associated with remodelling and thickening of the muscular walls, resulting in pulmonary hypertension.
Infants who develop MAS typically present in the first 12 hours after birth with varying degrees of respiratory distress. On inspection, many affected infants have 'barrel chests'; crackles (rales) and rhonchi often can be heard on auscultation. In severe cases, the entire lungs can be involved resulting in a total “whiteout” of the lungs on the radiograph.
Listeriosis is an infection that is acquired from the mother and is reported to be rarely associated with meconium-stained amniotic fluid.

A clinical picture of inspiratory stridor that worsens on crying and relieves in a prone position in a newborn without respiratory distress is suggestive of laryngomalacia.
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause of stridor in infants and children. Stridor is exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or feeding. In the prone position, the stridor disappears.

On laryngoscopy, an omega-shaped epiglottis is visualized.
In most children, only expectant observation is required as the condition resolves secondary to nervous system maturation, within 18 to 24 months of birth. However, neonates with severe laryngomalacia may develop marked upper airway obstruction resulting in cor pulmonale,

Thumb sign on lateral x-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis (AE). It is seen due to epiglottic enlargement.
AE is an inflammation of the epiglottis. The arytenoids, false cords, and posterior tongue may also be involved.
In children, Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause. This has decreased dramatically since the widespread availability of immunization (pentavalent). Streptococcus pyogenes, S. pneumoniae, and S. aureus have also been implicated. Non-infectious causes can be foreign body ingestion and trauma from thermal or caustic agents.
It has a progressive and potentially fulminating course, characterised by high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.
AE is a clinical diagnosis and a true emergency, X-ray soft tissue neck is not necessary to confirm it. It may be used to rule out differentials such as laryngotracheobronchitis, foreign body obstruction, retropharyngeal abscess or congenital anomalies. The time taken for X-rays should be avoided in a critically ill child due to the risk of sudden complete airway obstruction.
The definitive diagnosis of AE is made during direct laryngoscopy. However, since manipulation can induce a laryngospasm, it is generally avoided.

The history of progressive torticollis, neck pain and dysphagia in a young child along with a neck X-ray demonstrating a prevertebral soft-tissue swelling are all indicative of a retropharyngeal abscess. In young children, an antecedent upper respiratory tract infection is the most common cause of an RP abscess and not trauma.
It involves the suppuration of lymph nodes present in the RP space and is more common in children younger than 3-4 years since these lymph node chains involute after 5 years of age. Although lateral radiograph is used for initial imaging, CT of the neck with intravenous contrast is the best imaging study to evaluate patients with a retropharyngeal abscess. Treatment ranges from prolonged courses of intravenous antibiotics to surgical incision and drainage.

Solution to Question 2:
Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein.
The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava.
The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation. Note:
In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein. Mnemonic: AVA- artery –vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).
Solution to Question 3:
Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava.
The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta via
the umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and the rest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, the blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain.
Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part of the body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused by the right ventricle.

Delayed cord clamping entails the umbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation has ceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate to continue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.

Wide, variable splitting of S2 is a feature of VSD and not reverse splitting.
The basic defect in VSD is a left-to-right shunt which occurs at the ventricular level. During systole, the left ventricle empties into the aorta and the right ventricle via the VSD, because of which the total amount of blood in the right side of the heart increases, and that on the left decreases. Due to this increase, the right ventricle takes a longer time to empty causing a delayed P2 and on the other hand, the left ventricle empties sooner causing an early A2. This explains the wide S2. Variations due to respiration still happen and hence, the second heart sound is widely and variably split.
Auscultatory findings of VSD include a pansystolic murmur also known as Roger's murmur/shunt murmur can be best heard in the fourth left intercostal space. Flow murmurs that can be heard include, an MDM at the mitral area and an ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area.
A hyperdynamic precordium, a palpable P2, parasternal heave, a laterally displaced apical impulse, and a systolic thrill can be detected on palpation.

Solution to Question 14:
The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect.
Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.
The soft ejection systolic murmur is a flow murmur heard due to increased blood flow through the normal pulmonary valve. A delayed diastolic murmur can also be heard in the tricuspid area. As the right ventricle now receives more blood, the time required for its emptying is increased resulting in prolonged P2. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2.
Causes of Wide and fixed splitting of S2 include,
Atrial septal defect
RBBB

Other options:

VSD - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include a pansystolic murmur best heard in the left 4th parasternal area and a wide and variable split S2 which is usually masked by the pansystolic murmur.
PS - is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second interface and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.
Solution to Question 15:
Wide splitting of the 2nd heart sound with left axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) points to the diagnosis of ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD). Wide-fixed splitting of the 2nd heart sound is characteristic of ASD.
I ostium primum ASD, the basic abnormality is the combination of left-to-right shunt across the atrial defect and mitral insufficiency due to mitral valve clefts. Mitral valvular insufficiency increases the volume load on the left ventricle (seen as LAD & LVH on ECG). When mitral insufficiency is severe enough to cause clinical symptoms like fatigue on exertion, the left atrium enlarges as a result of the regurgitant flow, and the left ventricle becomes hypertrophied and dilated.
Solution to Question 16:
I atrial septal defect (ASD), there is a left-to-right shunt, resulting in increased blood flow through the right side of the heart, which leads to enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle and dilation of the pulmonary artery, the left atrium may also be enlarged, but the left ventricle and aorta are normal in size.
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): There is shunting of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary trunk, which goes into the lungs and then again to the LA and LV. If the ductus is large, left ventricular or biventricular hypertrophy is present.
I ventricular septal defect (VSD), there is shunting of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, but most of the blood is shunted directly to the inflow tract of the pulmonary trunk, so, there is no significant right ventricular hypertrophy. In VSD, the pulmonary artery left atrium, and left ventricle are enlarged.
I Tricuspid atresia, there is right to left shunting of blood through an ASD as the tricuspid valve is dysfunctional due to which the entire systemic venous return enters the left side of the heart using the foramen ovale or through an ASD, and hence, there is left ventricular hypertrophy.
Solution to Question 17:

Small ASDs (3 to <6mm in diameter) may grow smaller or close spontaneously. They do not cause symptoms and usually only need observation.
Transcatheter device or surgical closure is advised for:
All symptomatic patients
Asymptomatic patients with a Qp: Qs ratio of at least 2: 1
Those with RV enlargement.
ASD size >8mm
Closure (if indicated) is recommended before school entry. Repair is preferred during early childhood because surgical mortality and morbidity are significantly greater in adulthood.

I fective endocarditis is extremely rare in isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) and antibiotic prophylaxis for isolated ASDs is not recommended.
ASD is a low-pressure gradient defect whereas a high-pressure gradient across a defect is required to create a turbulent flow, which traumatizes the vascular endothelium, making the patient susceptible to endocarditis.
Patients with a small or moderate ASD are asymptomatic unless a complication occurs. Pulmonary hypertension, atrial dysrhythmias, tricuspid or mitral insufficiency, and heart failure may initially appear during the increased volume load of pregnancy.
