If the PDA is large, it can cause overloading of the left ventricle leading to cardiomegaly and congestive heart failure. Retrograde aortic flow, decreased systemic blood flow, and moderate hypotension is common in premature infants with a PDA predisposing them to necrotizing enterocolitis.
Solution to Question 20:
Differential cyanosis can be seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) when there is a reversal of shunt.
Differential cyanosis is manifested as cyanosis of only the lower extremities while upper extremities are unaffected. It is a result of reduced arterial oxygen saturation in the distal aorta compared to that in the aorta proximal to the left subclavian artery.
It is seen with:
right-to-left shunting across a ductus arteriosus in the presence of coarctation or an interrupted aortic arch
patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH)
The rest of the options cause cyanosis of all extremities. Among the options, PDA is the only condition that can manifest with differential cyanosis when there is a reversal of shunt.

Solution to Question 21:
The right upper limb is the best area to check pre-ductal oxygen saturation in a newborn infant as it receives blood supply primarily from the right brachial artery, which arises from the aorta before the ductus arteriosus.
I routine neonatal screening for critical congenital heart diseases (CCHD), saturation probes are placed on the right upper limb (pre-ductal) and the right lower limb (post-ductal) respectively.
If the difference between pre-ductal and post-ductal saturation is more than five percent, it confirms the presence of hypoxemia. Any reading showing an SpO2 <90% or greater than a three percent difference between the right hand and right foot for three successive readings separated by an hour each would suggest the presence of a congenital cardiac disease.
Screening is done to identify critical conditions before they present symptomatically, and before the neonate leaves the hospital post-delivery. This would allow for early and effective treatment of an underlying disease.
Critical congenital heart diseases include coarctation of the aorta, double outlet right ventricle, Ebstein anomaly, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, interrupted aortic arch, pulmonary atresia, single ventricle, tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC), d-transposition of the great arteries (TGA), tricuspid atresia, and truncus arteriosus.
Solution to Question 22:

Pansystolic or holosystolic murmurs begin almost simultaneously with the 1st heart sound and continue throughout systole (do not spill into diastole like a continuous murmur).
Continuous murmur is a systolic murmur that continues or “spills” into diastole and indicates continuous flow, such as in the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus or other aortopulmonary communication.

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformations: Large fistulas are associated with dyspnea, cyanosis, clubbing, a continuous murmur, and polycythemia, commonly associated with Osler Weber Rendu disease.

The most common cyanotic congenital heart disease is tetralogy of Fallot (ToF).
Infants are often asymptomatic until later in life (beyond 1yr of life). TOF has 4 components:
Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), an

(TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF. Clinical findings in TOF:
Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge.
Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve
Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces.
The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mil to moderate.
However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominent as the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT.

Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart:

Acyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow is mild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and less through the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis.

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.
Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.
Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.
Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
Solution to Question 5:
Squatting decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt in a child with tetralogy of Fallot
(TOF) .
The child feels comfortable while squatting due to two compensatory mechanisms:
Increasing systemic vascular resistance and, thus, decreasing the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Therefore, more blood goes to the lungs for oxygenation.
Trapping deoxygenated venous blood in the lower limbs.
Solution to Question 6:
Isoprenaline/isoproterenol should be avoided in tet or hypercyanotic spells. It will cause
a decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR) or systemic vascular resistance (SVR). So, more blood leaves the left ventricle leading to the increased right to left shunt. This results in the worsening of right ventricular outflow and causes worsening of cyanosis and the symptoms.
Treatment of hypercyanotic spell involves placing child in knee–chest position (or squatting), and use of:
oxygen
morphine - sedates the patient
sodium bicarbonate - to counteract metabolic acidosis that develops when arterial Po2 <40 mmHg
alpha-agonists (phenylephrine)- vasopressor used in severe cases
beta-blockers (propranolol)- improves resting saturation and decreases the frequency of spells.
Drugs that increase SVR, such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selective beta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-left shunt, and improve the symptoms. This is same principle as squatting.

The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) is supracardiac.
In TAPVC, pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly.
Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior venacava or left innominate vein.

Solution to Question 12:
Cyanosis at birth, prostagladin E1 administration, and septostomy to improve oxygenation are typical features of transposition of great vessels (TGA).
TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:
At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus
Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic “egg-on-string appearance”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels.
Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

Tricuspid regurgitation would be seen in a child with an Ebstein anomaly.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.
In Ebstein's, tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic and results in tricuspid regurgitation.
The right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow and there will be functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) results in cyanosis at birth.
Himalayan P wave (amplitude > 5 mm) is associated with tricuspid atresia, Ebstein anomaly, and combined tricuspid and pulmonary stenosis, where they indicate a dilated right atrium. Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome (WPW) and supraventricular tachycardia may be present in Ebstein anomaly.

Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium
Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle

This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent
congenital heart disease (CHD).

Functional closure of the PDA occurs soon after birth, usually within first week of life.
The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, thereby preventing the onset of cyanosis.
Upon its closure, cyanosis manifested in the baby as the blood could not be pumped into the lungs for oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood is being shunted into the systemic circulation after the closure of PDA. Hence, you should maintain the patency of the duct with PGE1 infusion until surgery can be done.

TOF is cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:
Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta)
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.
Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterised by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initially awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.
Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.

The reason for left atrial enlargement is due to increased pulmonary blood flow.
TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This abnormal configuration leads to a narrow vascular pedicle.
As pulmonary vascular resistance drops during the first few days of life, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature is increased. There is also elevated pulmonary venous pressure seen in TGA, especially in infants with an intact interventricular septum.
The globular (egg) appearance of the heart due to abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and the narrow superior mediastinum (string) result in the classical egg-on-string appearance.
TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers.
Early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy is a palliative catheter-based intervention that can be done to improve the hypoxic state before definitive surgery. The procedure creates an opening in the atrial septum which allows better
inter-circulatory mixing of the blood. Jatene arterial switch procedure is the definitive surgery. Most infants with TGA do not survive till adulthood without corrective surgery.

Primary: Due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2.
Secondary: Due to in utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

Membranous nephropathy:
Membranous nephropathy is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
It is classified as the primary, idiopathic form, where there is an isolated renal disease, or secondary, where nephropathy is associated with other identifiable systemic diseases or medications
In children, secondary form is far more common. The most common etiologies of secondary form are systemic lupus erythematosus or chronic infections. Among the latter, chronic hepatitis B infection and congenital syphilis are the best characterized and recognized causes.

Solution to Question 11:
The clinical presentation of a young girl with continuous dribbling of urine, despite normal voiding, strongly suggests the diagnosis of an ectopic ureter.
An ectopic ureter refers to a condition where the ureter drains outside the bladder. It is more common in females and opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. Hence, they present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (paradoxical incontinence).
The terminal part of the ureter is frequently narrowed, leading to hydroureteronephrosis. Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common due to urinary stasis.
In males, ectopic ureters usually enter the posterior urethra above the external sphincter, hence they are usually continent and most patients present with UTI or epididymitis.
Investigations include renal ultrasound (USG), voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), and renal scan to assess function. USG shows a hydronephrotic kidney or dilated upper pole and ureter. If there is a satisfactory function, the recommended treatment options are ureteral reimplantation into the bladder or ureteroureterostomy. The poor function may require partial or total nephrectomy.
Other options:
Option B: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, typically obstructive due to a small ureteral opening. In childhood, they commonly present with infections. Larger ureteroceles can cause obstruction at the bladder neck.
Option C: Congenital megaureter (dilated ureter) presents UTI, urinary stones, hematuria, and flank pain because of urinary stasis.
Option D: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the ureter and kidney. They usually present with recurrent attacks of UTI.

Severe segmental renal atrophy with loss of parenchymal elements in small kidneys is commonly known as segmental hypoplasia.

Solution to Question 1:
Holoprosencephaly is not a neural tube defect (NTD) and hence, it is the least likely diagnosis. Folic acid deficiency, especially in a young primigravida, is a risk factor for the development of NTDs in children, as seen in the given clinical vignette.
NTDs result from the failure of the neural tube to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development. These can be detected in antenatal ultrasound scans and subsequently managed for a better prognosis. The major NTDs include the following:
Spina bifida occulta
Meningocele
Myelomeningocele
Encephalocele
Anencephaly
Syringomyelia
Diastematomyelia (split spinal cord)
Iniencephaly
In holoprosencephaly, the forebrain fails to develop into two hemispheres due to mutations in the sonic hedgehog gene at the long arm of chromosome 7. It is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and the inadequate induction of the forebrain structures. The three types include, alobar, semilobar, and lobar, apart from the middle interhemispheric fusion variant or syntelencephaly.

Solution to Question 2:
A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn is suggestive of occult spinal dysraphism or neural tube defect. It comprises a range of conditions, including spina bifida occulta, intradural
lipoma, and dorsal dermal sinus.
Spinal dysraphism is due to the defective fusion of the midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures. Associated clinical features are high-arched feet, muscle size and strength differences between legs, and abnormal walking patterns. In newborns and young infants, the neurological examination is usually normal, but older children may experience a lack of sensation in the perineal area and back pain.
Most of the patients will have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, including a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma.
The image shows a tuft of hair in a case of spinal dysraphism:

Spinal dysraphism also includes meningocele, myelomeningocele, lipomeningocele, diastematomyelia (split spinal cord), thickened filum terminale, and cauda equina tumour.
The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.
Spina bifida is the most common type of spinal dysraphism, in which the spinal column does not close completely, leaving the spinal cord and its protective covering exposed.

Myelomeningocele is the most severe form of spina bifida, where the spinal cord and nerve roots are exposed and may be damaged. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly and hydrocephalus in newborns.
Ventriculomegaly is the dilation of the ventricles. When ventriculomegaly occurs in association with raised cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, it is called hydrocephalus.
Pathologic etiologies can be congenital or acquired. Congenital causes include structural abnormalities such as aqueductal stenosis, agenesis of the corpus callosum, Dandy-Walker malformations, Chiari malformations, and neural tube defects. Treatment for aqueductal stenosis includes ventriculostomy, diuretics, serial lumbar punctures in specific cases, and CSF diversion. In severe cases, CSF diversion procedures (shunting), may be necessary to redirect the flow of CSF and relieve pressure on the brain.

Antibiotic prophylaxis is provided to the close contacts of persons with confirmed meningococcal disease.
Close contacts of individuals with confirmed meningococcal disease are at an increased risk of developing the illness. Prophylaxis is also offered to individuals with direct and prolonged contact with a case of meningococcal disease. Antibiotics are effective in preventing additional cases by eradicating the carriage of the invasive strain.
Treatment is provided to the contacts within 24 hours of identification of the index case. The antibiotics effective include rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin.
Prophylaxis is not generally recommended for medical personnel, except in cases where there is exposure to aerosols of respiratory secretions, such as during mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, intubation, or suctioning. This recommendation applies within 24 hours before or after the initiation of antibiotic therapy in the index case.
For the treatment of cases, penicillin is the preferred drug, but ceftriaxone or other
third-generation cephalosporins are recommended for patients with penicillin allergy. Droplet infection control precautions should be followed for hospitalized patients for 24 hours after effective therapy has been initiated.
Offering quadrivalent meningococcal A, C, W, Y conjugate vaccines in addition to antimicrobial prophylaxis can further reduce the risk of disease among close contacts of cases caused by vaccine capsular groups.
Meningococcal vaccines are available in two forms: polysaccharide vaccines and
polysaccharide-protein conjugate vaccines. Polysaccharide vaccines can be given as a single dose to individuals aged 2 years and older. They are offered in bivalent (A, C), trivalent (A, C, W135), and quadrivalent (A, C, W135, Y) formulations.
Meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available as monovalent (A or C) or quadrivalent (A, C, W135, Y) formulations. Conjugate vaccines, which offer increased immunogenicity and potential for herd protection, are preferred over polysaccharide vaccines, especially in children under 2 years of age. Isolation of the child is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy after being diagnosed with acute bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission.
Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitides and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.
The child with meningitis shows nonspecific symptoms like fever, anorexia, poor feeding, headache, myalgia, hypotension, petechia, purpura, or a rash. Meningial irritation is indicated by nuchal rigidity, back pain, and Kernig, and Brudzinski signs (usually not seen in infants).
Seizures and altered mental status may be present.
The recommended empirical antibiotic regimen in a suspected case of meningitis outside the neonatal period is vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin. Patients allergic to penicillin or cephalosporin can be treated with meropenem, fluoroquinolones, or chloramphenicol.
Chemoprophylaxis with rifampicin/ceftriaxone/ciprofloxacin is recommended for all close contacts with meningococcal meningitis regardless of age or immunization status. Rifampicin prophylaxis should be given to all household contacts of patients with invasive disease caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b, if an immunocompromised child of any age resides in the household or close family member younger than 48 months has not been fully immunized.

Skull fractures associated with a dural tear may fail to heal properly. The herniated brain, dilated ventricles, or a leptomeningeal cyst may cause an enlargement of this tear. These fractures are called growing skull fractures. They are usually seen in children < 3 years of age.
They present as a localized swelling or palpable skull defect that increases in size, most commonly seen in the parietal region. However, they may go undetected for years and present with delayed onset of neurologic symptoms (headache, seizure, or neurologic deficit).

Solution to Question 32:
Decerebrate or decorticate posturing is not seen in brain death as they are motor responses to noxious stimuli that originate from the midbrain and cortex.
Brain death, also known as death by neurologic criteria refers to the irreversible and total cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brainstem.
The three components for diagnosing brain death are a demonstration of coexisting irreversible coma with a known cause, absence of brain stem reflexes, and apnea. Coma requires the patient to be unresponsive, even to noxious stimuli. The diagnosis of brain death can still be made despite positive spinal reflexes. (option B)
Brainstem reflexes (pupillary responses, oculocephalic reflex, oculovestibular responses, corneal reflex, jaw reflex, facial grimacing, pharyngeal gag reflex, coughing) are absent. Apnea is the absence of respiratory drive at PaCO2 of 60mmHg and > 20mmHg above baseline, which is consistent with brain death.
The following manifestations are occasionally seen and should not be misinterpreted as evidence of brainstem function:
Normal systolic blood pressure - SBP >100 mmHg (option A)
Movements originating from the spinal cord or peripheral nerve may occur
Sweating, flushing, tachycardia (option C)
Deep tendon reflexes; superficial abdominal reflexes; triple flexion response
Babinski reflex
Spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathologic flexion or extension response
Respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back-arching, intercosta expansion without significant tidal volumes)

Solution to Question 3:
Under virilizing type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is not caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
Depending on the extent of enzyme deficiency, CAH caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency is broadly classified into classic and non-classic forms:
Classic forms can be of two types - salt-wasting and simple virilizing types.
Salt-wasting type is the severe form in which both cortisol and aldosterone are deficient, with excess androgen production.
In the simple virilizing type, there is an impaired synthesis of cortisol and adequate amounts of aldosterone. Here, clinical features are due to the overproduction of androgens.
The non-classic form is characterized by partial 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Cortisol and aldosterone are produced normally, but at the expense of producing excess androgens.

Normal genitalia in female children rules out congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) caused by 21-hydroxylase and 3-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia rule out CAH due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency and 11-hydroxylase deficiency.

Infants with aldosterone synthase deficiency may have severe electrolyte abnormalities with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic

Since cortisol synthesis is unaffected, infants rarely become as ill as untreated infants with salt-losing forms of CAH. So some infants escape diagnosis at birth because of normal cortisol levels.
Later in infancy or in early childhood, they may exhibit failure to thrive and poor growth.
Adults often are asymptomatic, although they may develop electrolyte abnormalities when depleted of sodium through procedures such as bowel preparation for a barium enema.

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency due to acquired lesions of the adrenal cortex, which prevent the production of cortisol and, often, aldosterone. Hence, due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, there will be hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension.
The deficiency of cortisol stimulates the production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Increased ACTH leads to diffuse hyperpigmentation, including areas not exposed to the sun, such as buccal mucosa and gums.

Solution to Question 19:
The clinical scenario of hyperpigmentation, history of bilateral adrenalectomy and MRI showing enlarged pituitary adenoma points to the diagnosis of Nelson's syndrome.
Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.
The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one.
Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:
Hyperpigmentation
Excessive ACTH secretion
Corticotroph adenoma
Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.
The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common tumor associated with growth hormone (GH) deficiency in children is craniopharyngioma.

Solution to Question 2:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point
towards Laron syndrome/dwarfism. It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to the GH receptor mutation. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features as those seen in pituitary dwarfism.
Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.
In Turner's syndrome (Option A), loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization.
Pituitary dwarfism (Option B) is a condition with GH deficiency.
Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D) is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone deficiencies
(MPHD)/panhypopituitarism is the mutation of the PROP1 gene. LHX3 and GLI2 are other genes involved in MPHD.
GNAS1 mutations cause McCune Albright Syndrome. c-MYC gene is mutated in Burkitt's lymphoma
WT-1 gene is mutated in Wilms tumors.
Solution to Question 4:
Children with growth hormone deficiency usually have normal growth at birth. Growth retardation (decline in growth velocity) becomes apparent around 1 year of age.
Growth in-utero is dependant on genetic, environmental, nutrition and growth factors. GH levels peak at mid-gestation, increase at birth, and then reduce by 2 weeks of life. At around 6 months of age, GH levels reach pre-pubertal levels and from there on have a major influence on
growth. Thus the deficiency becomes apparent after a significant period of GH-dependent growth has occurred.
Characteristic features of growth hormone deficiency (Pituitary Dwarfism):
Normal growth at birth with growth retardation becoming apparent around 1 year of age
Proportionate short stature
Hypoglycemic seizures in newborn
Small larynx with a high-pitched voice
Small genitalia (micropenis)
Delayed skeletal maturation
Delayed dentition
Delayed puberty (sexual infantilism)
Doll-like facial appearance: small, round facies, frontal prominence, depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose), eyes may bulge, underdeveloped mandible and chin, normal head circumference but craniofacial disproportion due to small facies
Short neck
Normal intelligence.

Chronic kidney disease is an FDA-approved indication for growth hormone (GH) therapy.
Renal failure is a state of GH resistance. Moderate-to-severe growth retardation in chronic kidney disease is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. GH therapy with recombinant growth hormone has been shown to improve catch-up growth and to allow the child to achieve normal adult height; the final adult height is still significantly below the genetic target.

Solution to Question 9:
"Weak giants" are due to hyperpituitarism that is most commonly produced by pituitary adenomas.
Hyperpituitarism causes growth hormone (GH) excess, leading to tall stature (giants) with weak muscles. Overproduction of GH results in gigantism in children (before fusion of bone growth plate) and acromegaly in adults.
Clinical features include:
Gigantism, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones
Proximal myopathy (though there is muscle hypertrophy, it is weakened due to atrophy of type II muscle fibers)
Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues)
Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, spleen, kidney, and prostate
Local effects of the adenoma: Headache, visual field defects, raised ICT
Note: Although hypothalamic hamartomas can also produce gigantism, the most common cause of gigantism is pituitary adenomas.
Solution to Question 10:
Lesions in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus can cause central diabetes insipidus.
These nuclei synthesize vasopressin, a 9-amino-acid peptide with antidiuretic and vascular pressor activity. It is transported to the posterior pituitary via axonal projections, where it is stored for release into the systemic circulation.
Diabetes insipidus (DI) is characterized by pathologic polyuria and polydipsia (>2 L/m²/24 hr or 5 mL/kg/hr). It can result from either:
Vasopressin deficiency (decreased anti-diuretic hormone production) causes central DI.
Vasopressin insensitivity at the level of the kidney causes nephrogenic DI.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The treatment of choice is desmopressin. It is a vasopressin analog (V2 receptor agonist). It can be administered intranasally, or subcutaneously.
Option A: Leuprolide is a GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) analog used in the treatment of prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis.
Option B: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drug of choice. They are generally used in nephrogenic DI.
Option D: Terlipressin is a long-acting analog on vasopressin that acts on V1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. It is used as a vasopressor in shock and acute variceal bleeding.

Diabetes Insipidus

Neural Deafness
It is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome.
Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients with JMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations.

Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20% of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for this type of leukemia.
JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneous resolution.

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.
Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin.
Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.

Solution to Question 1:
The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness and waddling gait are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is
an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles which occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is paradoxically weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.
Clinical features:
Progressive weakness with developmental delay
Pseudohypertrophy of calves
Wasting of thigh muscles
Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle.
Gower’s sign
Dilated cardiomyopathy Diagnosis:
Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for dystrophin gene
If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.
Note- The FDA has approved Vamorolone, a novel corticosteroid for the treatment of DMD. The rug offers enhanced anti-inflammatory properties and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonism as well. It is potentially a safer and more effective alternative to glucocorticoids.
Other options:
Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late.
Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early.
Option D: Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular and humeral muscles. The given question describes the involvement of lower limb muscles. Hence, Emery–Dreifuss dystrophy, in this case, is less likely.
Solution to Question 2:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene.
This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Becker’s dystrophy is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a genetic defect at the same locus (Xp21) but clinically less severe. Gene affected in both is dystrophin, which is the largest gene in humans.

Solution to Question 5:
The image shows winging of the scapula, which when combined with this patient's features are suggestive of facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy.
Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents with asymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles. Occasionally, finger and wrist weakness is the first symptom.
The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips. Upper facial weakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. Scapular winging is prominent, even in infants. Flattening or even concavity of the deltoid contour is seen, and the biceps and triceps brachii muscles are wasted and weak. Eventually, proximal muscles get involved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear. Lumbar lordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.
Treatment includes orthopedic measures for scoliosis and foot drop, surgical intervention for scapular deformity. Physiotherapy has no value.
Other options:

low posterior hairline

Myotonic dystrophy patients have a characteristic V-shaped upper lip, a history of myotonia, and progressive weakness.
Solution to Question 6:
The clinical picture showing pain in the calves occuring within a week of an upper respiratory tract infection (URI), with elevated creatine kinase levels suggests the diagnosis of viral myositis. The specific history of URI suggests influenza myositis.
Infectious myositis has a male predominance and is typically seen in young adults. Childhood form presents with fever, malaise, and rhinorrhea and is usually followed by severe pain, especially in the calves. The muscle pain is usually worse with movement and the symptoms last for about a week. In children, toe walking and wide-based gait may be seen because of the involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.
Other viral causes of myositis include HIV-1 (one of the most common causes of myositis), group B coxsackievirus (epidemic myalgia), HTLV-1 (Human T-lymphotropic virus), and cytomegalovirus (CMV).
Lab features of influenza myositis include elevated CK which may be as high as 500 times normal the value. Urine myoglobin is usually positive. Detection of the virus with PCR testing of nasopharyngeal specimens can be carried out but is not of much clinical significance. The histopathological examination would reveal muscle fiber necrosis without much inflammatory change.
Treatment includes bed rest, IV fluids, and symptomatic management with analgesics and antipyretics. Amantadine and other antiviral agents may be considered in adults. Complications include myocarditis and respiratory dysfunction. Rhabdomyolysis is an uncommon complication.
Solution to Question 7:
Among the given options, only Spinal muscular atrophy presents in infancy. The rest present in late childhood.
Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a degenerative disease of motor neurons, that is inherited in
an autosomal recessive manner. It usually starts in infancy with hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and thin muscle mass (atrophy). Polyhydramnios may be present prenatally due to weakness in swallowing.
Diagnosis is done by genetic testing for SMN gene mutation. Muscle biopsy is done for cases with negative genetic testing and strong clinical suspicion. The muscle biopsy in infancy shows a characteristic pattern of perinatal denervation that is unlike that of a mature muscle. Groups of giant type I fibers are mixed with fascicles of severely atrophic fibers.
Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Recent updates:
Nusinersen is an antisense oligonucleotide approved by the FDA for treating SMA. It is administered intrathecally.
Risdiplam (first oral drug) has been approved by FDA to treat infants >2 months of age with SMA. It is an oral splicing modifier that corrects the splicing defect of SMN2, which leads to
increased levels of full-length SMN protein.

Though the gold standard investigation is a muscle biopsy, it is indicated only when the diagnosis is in doubt or when grading of the disease severity is required. Nerve conduction studies are usually normal unless associated with severe muscle necrosis and atrophy. Electromyography would show the characteristic signs of myopathy and muscle fiber necrosis but is preferably performed in a specialized center.

A severe congenital form of myotonic dystrophy appears in infants born to mothers with symptomatic myotonic dystrophy. It is inherited as an autosomal-dominant trait. Clinical features include:
Skeletal deformities (clubfoot deformities alone or congenital contractures involving many joints and can even include the cervical spine).
Generalized hypotonia and weakness at birth
Facial wasting and weakness
Inverted V-shaped upper lip
Loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossa
Infants can require gavage feeding or ventilator support for respiratory muscle weakness or apnea.

Brittle bone disease is another name for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is due to defects in type 1 collagen, not type 2 collagen.
There are 12 types of OI, with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera, and deafness is known as van der Hoeve syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapy and orthopedic rehabilitation.

Anemia and hepatosplenomegaly in an infant with the X-ray image showing dense bones, and bone within the bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis.
Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease
It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 in osteoclasts.
Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anemia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels are observed. Radiological features include diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen (image). Treatment is symptomatic. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done in severe cases.
Achondroplasia usually presents with pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, obstructive sleep apnea, and recurrent infections.
In both scurvy and osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), the child cries on touching. On radiography, certain typical features are seen in scurvy, while multiple fractures are seen in OI.

Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus(NLE):
NLE is not an autoimmune condition. It occurs when maternal autoantibodies enter the fetal circulation (passive transfer). The antibodies responsible for this condition are anti-Ro antibody (anti-SSA) and anti-La antibody (anti-SSB).
The periorbital rash typically appears within 6 weeks of life and lasts 3-4 months. However, it can be present at birth. Infants may also have cytopenias and hepatitis, but the most feared complication is congenital heart block. Cardiomyopathy is seen in the most severe cases. The noncardiac manifestations of neonatal lupus are usually reversible, whereas congenital heart block is permanent. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age.
Fluorinated corticosteroids seem to improve cases of hydrops. Significant conduction system abnormalities after birth are treated with cardiac pacing and occasionally intravenous immunoglobulin and steroids, while severe cardiomyopathy may require cardiac transplantation. Transient, noncardiac manifestations are conservatively managed, with topical steroids used occasionally to treat the rash.
Other options:
Anti-Jo antibodies are a type of myositis-specific antibodies. These are not related to neonatal lupus.
Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus erythematosus). Anti-histone antibodies are present in Drug-induced SLE.

The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).
HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.
The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.
Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash.
Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information
Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants
like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.

Properties of fetal hemoglobin (HbF)
HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.
This property forms the basis of the alkali denaturation test (or Apt test) to detect the presence of fetal blood in maternal circulation in suspected feto-maternal hemorrhage.
The Kleihauer–Betke test (or acid elution test) is used to quantitate the amount of feto-materna hemorrhage to calculate the dosage of anti-D required in Rh-negative mothers.

Increased HbF can be seen in hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, sickle cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, HbC disease, and HbE disease
HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen.
This allows for gas exchange from maternal circulation by binding to oxygen at a relatively low oxygen tension in the maternal blood supplying the chorion.
HbF has lower affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) than HbA.
Lack of interaction between HbF and 2,3 BPG increases the affinity of HbF to oxygen.

ITP is a bleeding disorder and has prolonged bleeding time, low platelet count, and normal coagulation profile (prothrombin time [PT] and activated partial thromboplastin time [aPTT]).

Classification system for ITP:
No symptoms.
Mild symptoms- bruising and petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis which has very little interference with daily living.

The older child (4 yr) with severe ITP that has lasted >1 year (chronic ITP) and whose symptoms are not easily controlled with therapy

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder.
VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF).
VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation.
Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosoma recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 1 disease.
Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.

Solution to Question 11:
The ristocetin-aggregation test is abnormal in both von Willebrand disease and Bernard–Soulier syndrome.
All of the above diseases are inherited bleeding disorders affecting platelet function. Hence, there is prolonged bleeding time but platelet levels are not significantly affected.
Platelet aggregation tests use a panel of platelet agonists (adenosine diphosphate [ADP],
epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin) to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Ristocetin induces the binding of VWF to platelets and agglutinates platelets.
Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a severe congenital platelet function disorder, is caused by an absence or severe deficiency of the VWF receptor on the platelet membrane. Hence, in Bernard–Soulier syndrome, no response (or no aggregation) is seen with ristocetin.
The ristocetin-aggregation test is also abnormal in von Willebrand disease. However, it normalizes after the addition of normal plasma (which contains vWF) since there is no defect in binding receptors.

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) refers to a life-threatening pulmonary complication of sickle cell disease. It is diagnosed with the presence of a new radiodensity on chest radiography with any 2 of the following:
Fever
Respiratory distress
Hypoxia
Coug
Chest pain
In this case, the child with sickle cell anemia satisfies the above criteria. He presented with chest pain and respiratory distress and his chest X-ray image shows new radiodensities.
Most patients with ACS do not have a single identifiable cause. Infection is the most well-known etiology, yet only 30% of ACS episodes will have positive sputum or bronchoalveolar culture. The most common bacterial pathogens implicated are S. pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia spp.
Oxygen should be supplemented to all patients who demonstrate hypoxia.
Blood transfusion is the only method to abort a rapidly progressing episode of ACS.
Because of the clinical overlap between pneumonia and ACS, all episodes should be treated promptly with antimicrobial therapy, including at least a macrolide and possibly a
third-generation cephalosporin.
Regular use of an incentive spirometer at 10-12 breaths every 2 hours can significantly reduce the frequency of subsequent acute chest pain episodes.

Solution to Question 11:
Rh incompatibility causes immune hydrops fetalis, whereas alpha-thalassemia, parvovirus B19 infection, and twin-twin transfusion syndrome cause non-immune hydrops fetalis.
Hydrops fetalis refers to the abnormal fluid collections in fetal soft tissues and serous cavities. Edema, signs of heart failure, and profound intra-uterine anemia are the presenting
features in the fetus. Other clinical features include marked hepatosplenomegaly, retardation in brain growth, hydrocephaly, urogenital and cardiovascular deformities, and extramedullary erythropoiesis.
Non-immune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) comprises the subgroup of cases not caused by red cell alloimmunization (e.g., Rh(D), Kell)
Bart's hydrops fetalis (alpha-thalassemia) is caused by the deletion or inactivation of all four alpha-globin alleles, leading to a severe deficiency in alpha-globin chains of Hb and to the
production of gamma-4 tetramers (Hb Bart). Hb Bart tetramers have an extremely high oxygen affinity and are incapable of effective tissue oxygen delivery.
Parvovirus B19 infection can cause fetal anemia, non-immune fetal hydrops, and fetal death.

The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusion, low hemoglobin level, and target cells in the smear are suggestive of thalassemia. Globin gene sequencing is used for its definitive diagnosis.
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used as a screening test for thalassemia

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into -thalassemia and -thalassemia.
-thalassemia is caused by point mutations of the -thalassemia gene on chromosome 11, whic diminish the synthesis of -globin chains. Splicing mutations are the most common cause of (+) thalassemia.
There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in
-thalassemia. Children with severe thalassemia present with distinctive facial features such as maxilla hyperplasia, a flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing. Other manifestations include pathologic bone fractures, significant hepatosplenomegaly, and cachexia.
Blood smears show marked anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.
Hb Electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are used as screening tests for thalassemia. DNA diagnosis to detect -thalassemia mutations is used for definitive diagnosis. The Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and -thalassemia trait. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor syndrome.
Transfusions are administered every 3-4 weeks to maintain a pretransfusion hemoglobin level of 9.5-10.5 g/dL. Transfusion-induced hemosiderosis is a significant complication in
transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Iron deposition occurs in the liver, endocrine organs, and heart, resulting in complications including hypothyroidism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, growth hormone deficiency, hypoparathyroidism, diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and arrhythmias.

Solution to Question 17:
Crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on X-ray imaging of the skull is due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, which is seen in thalassemia.
Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis, which causes the widening of the diploic space, thereby causing the thickening of trabeculae. This results in the classical crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on x-ray imaging of the skull. Extramedullary hematopoiesis also leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face, leading to the characteristic chipmunk facies in thalassemia.
